title: Do you like rap music? - Quora

response.answer_text:
I like hiphop and rap quite a lot, but only the select few talented rappers of the 2000s that did not purely rap about money, guns, drugs, sex, and fame. I feel like this website explains things pretty well, but I will summarise the information. Egotism Many rap songs, especially those today, brag about their fame, “street cred,” and money. Honestly, hiphop is an art, and their is more to it than just boasting about yourself. Sexism While others genres are about heartbreak, finding true love, and the joy of being with the woman you love, rap and hiphop these days has always been about objectifying women into nothing more than objects for sex. Lack of Talent You honestly don’t need much talent to be a famous rapper. Of course, this doesn’t apply to all rap legends, such as Eminem (Rhyme King), Biggie (Flow King), or Tupac (Lyricist King) [Sorry if I didn’t mention your favourite rapper, these are just the ones I can think of off the top of my head]. I am talking about the rappers that don’t even write their own lyrics, and when they do, they use simple, ABAB rhymes that require no skill whatsoever. These are the top 3 pet peeves of mine when it comes to bad rap music, but there are some examples of good, meaningful songs as well. Eminem – Mockingbird | A song Eminem wrote to his daughter. Yes.But not this rap music  But this rap  Here is the difference in lyrics Lil Yachty(first guy) - https://www.azlyrics.com/lyrics/lilyachty/1night.html (can’t include lyrics there becuase quora will probably collapse this answer then) Wu Tang Clan - impossible Can you imagine from one single idea, everything appeared hereUnderstanding makes my truth, crystal clearInnocent black immigrants locked in housing tenemantsEighty-Five percent tenants depend on welfare recipientsStapleton's been stamped as a concentration campAt night I walk through, third eye is bright as a street lampElectric microbes, all body clothesTaking telescope pictures of globe, babies getting pierced with microchipsstuffed inside their earlobes, then examinatedBlood contaminated, vaccinated, lives fabricatedExaggerated authorization, Food and Drug AdministrationTestin poison in prison population RZA used more different words in one song than all mumble rappers in all of their songs.Today’s rap is about guys talking about shooting people they don’t like even though they have never held a gun.It’s about drugs and living rich and it’s repetitive.Some of old school rappers also rapped about drugs but they had rhymes and not all of their songs were about the same thing.

Not generally but there are a few raps I’ve found creative over the years. My favorite Frankenstein rap is “How ya Like Me Now” by Kool Moe Dee. I call it Frankenstein rap because the entire musical track consists of sampled instruments from other records. I’m not big on sampling because it strikes me as stealing more or less and a way for “musicians” to create music without actually creating it. They are to music what Dr. Frankenstein was to life. I liked “Bust a Move” and Funky Cold Medina” because there actually was a musical track behind the rappers. Which leads me to the phrase in the question “rap music.” Music is a combination of melody, harmony, rhythm and in some genres lyrics. Rap essentially has no melody or harmony which to me, means its rhythm and lyrics have to be super strong to sustain the art form. Often, they just aren’t. Thus, I don’t listen to a lot of rap because the musical form is stunted by definition. But like all musical genres, it has its showcase examples to legitimize the art form.

Asking if I like rap music sounds a lot like asking if I like rock music: both genres are so evolved, and so global - it’s really hard to pin them down to any single style, any single place, or even any single genre (lotta fusion around, these days). For instance, here’s one that I never get tired of - it’s absolutely my favorite hip-hop / rap ode to the creator of the periodic table of elements.  Then, jumping over to Turkey — I don’t speak Turkish, but I very much like the catchy vibes of this song, including the rap portions.  Moving on to India, they seem to get rap there, too - per the nearly 200 million views this video has received. So far.  And of course there’s, well, this - a video with a memorable bit of rap in it - that currently enjoys the #1 spot, in terms of video views, ever. 3.75 Billion with a B …. and counting.  And so - yes, I like rap music. And, apparently, so do a lot of other people — all over the world.

An unequivocal, definite, yes. I’m a musician. At my core, I love music. Of the music I love, I have a lot of favorites. I’m a huge fan of jazz, and if I were to label myself with a genre, I’d call myself a jazz musician, foremost. I like crazy 20th century percussion ensemble works. John Cage is one of my idols. And I like the kind of pop that Marina and the Diamonds’ “Electra Heart” is- upbeat, danceable, but a little moody and cynical, while telling a story. I don’t know if there’s a word for that, but whatever that word is, that’s a genre I really dig. But above all of that, I love rap. I grew up with rap. By the time I was old enough to talk, I knew all the words to songs by Eminem, Tupac, 50 Cent, Snoop Dogg, etc… My mom showed me off to her friends a few times, rapping Eminem’s “Mockingbird.” I didn’t even know what the songs were about then, they just sounded good to me. I grew up in a town overflowing with poverty, gang violence, and drug trade. You can probably imagine that rap was the dominating music choice in my hometown, even before the current boom in its popularity, nationwide. So I was essentially surrounded by rap from birth, and as I grew older, it was more and more ingrained into my being- for a while, I’d stick to what I knew, which was whatever I could pull from my mom’s CD collections. Around age 12–13, I decided that I didn’t like rap, because some guy on the internet told me it was mindless anti-music, and I wanted to seem older and sophisticated. I outgrew that phase pretty quickly, thankfully. And when I did, it was like I’d been going through a rap withdrawal for months- suddenly, I was listening to all kinds of rap that I’d never listened to before. I was checking out Kanye and Lil Wayne, both pretty big at the time, and I even swerved (very briefly) into ICP territory. I got really into Hollywood Undead after a friend sent me a bootleg copy of “Notes from the Underground.” And somewhere along the way, I ran across some stuff by Tech N9ne, and I was hooked instantly. At that point, I’d solidified my taste in rap as “all the old stuff I grew up on, and also some new stuff.” I know, I know, very specific. I’ll listen to about anything once, y’know? By the time I made it to college, I was devouring rap by the album, digging mostly into the older stuff. I was blasting Wu-Tang and Quest from my admittedly pitiful laptop speakers most days. Freshman year, a friend introduced me to Kendrick Lamar, and I haven’t been able to stop listening to him since. The man is a genius. He took two of my favorite musical genres and smashed them together into what I honestly believe to be one of the greatest albums of all times. And three years later, I’m working my way through tons of newer stuff, and more niche tracks and albums that I find along the way. Just today, I stumbled across Zebra Katz’ “I’ma Read” in a Quora answer. My best friend’s dad, who’s more of a metal-and-country kind of guy, showed me Downer’s “Suga Boom Boom,” which is one of my favorite songs now, another friend showed me Meek Mills’ “Lord Knows,” which was stuck in my head for weeks. I’m always looking for new songs to listen to, especially rap. And now I spend a bit of my time every week converting people to the rap side of the force. And usually, assuming the person is open to new music, and is able to clearly express what they don’t like about rap, I’m often successful at clearing misconceptions and matching people to artists and songs they’d like. Makes me feel like all the time I spend listening to new music is paying off, whenever I get someone to go from saying “I hate rap,” to saying, “I still won’t listen to Gucci Mane, but I like that one Snoop Dogg song, and ‘untitled unmastered’ is my new favorite album.” I don’t just like rap. I breathe it, and eat it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner (which is for beginners, you ain’t even know.) Now here’s a bunch of songs I like, if you want to have a listen.  “Suga Boom Boom” - Downer  “Lord Knows” - Meek Mill  “I’ma Read” - Zebra Katz  “Mockingbird” - Eminem  “Rain” - Hollywood Undead  “Warpath” - Drezus  “Regulate” - Nate Dogg ft. Warren G  “Bonita Applebum” - A Tribe Called Quest  “Fragile” - Tech N9ne ft. Kendrick Lamar, MAYDAY!, and Kendall Morgan

Nope. Didn't like it as a teen/early twentysomething when I first heard it in the 80s; still can't stand it. I want to listen to singing, not talking. So much of it is hate-filled, too. I'm not going to waste valuable time listening to somebody spew hatred and espouse violence.

I like some of it, but not much that has come out since about 1990. Many people, my friends included, think all rap is gangster rap. I don’t like any of that, but I still have dozens and dozens of CD’s and LP’s, meaning I have been into it since the days when you had to pay money for it.

So long as the music is something I like, it doesn't really matter. However, I'm disabled, due to severe stroke, so often need physical help from a “carer” — who usually gets a free ticket! Thus, a few days ago i heard the Moscow Philharmonic orchestra playing an all-Russian programme in Leeds Town Hall so I travelled and was helped by a very good friend. We both enjoyed the concert tremendously. Then in a fortnight I'll travel to Chichester cathedral to hear the Beethoven “Emperor” concerto and will be helped by my first girlfriend (we met in 1959!) who enjoys classical concerts but as a single woman is a little nervous about travelling by herself… so yes, it's nice to have company!

I honesty like both. If I'm with my friends in the car, then yeah, I enjoy listening to the radio with them. If I'm by myself, in my room, in the car, listening to music through headphones, I will sing along and belt my heart out. So, it depends on my mood and how much I really like those people.

Based on my music taste? I like no song that my friends like. So I listen to my music alone, and I’m forced to listen to that pop and rap… noise at nightclubs, on special occasions when I happen to be out with friends. Thankfully I found a bar in my area that plays the exact type of music I want.. yeah the oldies and stuff.. so I don’t have to listen alone anymore, heh. And it has some of the best food, so it’s like heaven for me. But yeah, apart from that, I listen to music alone, not in a sad way at all, always in the search of hidden gems from long ago. My friends are not really as fascinated by the 70s/80s as I am because my country, Albania, is one amongst the many countries deeply affected by the pop culture. But that’s totally fine by me. I’ve met many people online that share the same music taste as I do, and that’s awesome. I wouldn’t ask for anything more.
No it is not music.
No.

If it’s about the music, it’s so much better alone. whenever I try to share music with someone or they with me, the song kind of fades to the background and it’s more about being with the person. I stop paying attention to the song and I wonder about their tastes and if they like it. I imagine them doing the same with me. And honestly I often forget the group they just shared. Instead I feel happy that we just got to be together. However when friends recommended a group and I listened on my own, the music sticks with me and I often find my favorite bands that way. Later I connect back with them and can find a deeper connection from genuine common interest. So I totally recommend both. If it’s a new artist I think it’s better to digest it on your own but when you both like the song, it can be very special to share it then.
Alone. Outside of serious musicians, who in the hell would be able to listen to Mahavishnu Orchestra, Return to Forever, or early George Benson before he sold out to mainstream Top 40?

I have been listening to rap music since I was a kid. It helped me when I was in deep depression. I am not referring to the style that most people always refer to, as too aggressive, when they talk about rap. I am talking about the ones that really had meanings. Rappers like Tupac, Eminem (some of it) and Jay-Z are the ones who have produced the songs that I like.
THEY LEFT THE C OUT IT.
yes.
I dislike most rap music and, in fact, do not consider much of the rap I have heard to actually be music.

I rather prefer both. music alone is therapeutic, reflective and creates a space of peace in the conscious mind. music with friends is fun and a great conversation starter. good music also makes for fun fodder when it comes to impromptu karaoke sessions. Lol. Music is good for many reasons. Reasons which can be too many to outline.
There is no reason not to listen to a rap music. It is full of energy and flows that energy to the listeners.
Sometimes, rappers like Logic, NF etc. But I mostly listen to country and rock.
I hate most of rap music because it never portrays anything positive in the lyrics
Any time and All the time.
